posts.name: Henry Mahnke
posts.cooked: We changed our can to star can which uses a single main line running along the base of our robot, and as we add resistors at the end of our swerve modules, everything was fine. Once we added 2 more lines for new mechanisms and got a total of 6 (120 ohms) resistors, our entire can network goes down. We were under the impression that you needed a resistor to terminate at every end. But we are wondering if because the resistors are in parallel with the can network, we are decreasing the resistance with each resistor, and as we increase resistors, we are decreasing the circuit’s total resistance and that’s somehow messing everything up. We can run the robot around with no resistors, but we thought reflections would be prominent with no resistors and that would screw up everything as well. Any help is appreciated.

posts.name: Chadfrom7226
posts.cooked:
You should only have 2x 120 Ohm resistors for a CAN network (total of 60 Ohm resistance on the bus)

The resistors help with reflections and signal integrity

Only use 2 120 ohm resistors, one on each of your longest CAN wire runs

posts.name: Drakxii
posts.cooked: How long are your CAN runs?

posts.name: Eric Tate
posts.cooked:
The layout you describe is more of a “trunk and tap” layout than a star. This is similar to how CAN is implemented in some industrial protocols like DeviceNet.

As I recall, in DeviceNet you place a termination at the end of the Trunk and not at the end of each Tap.

I suspect you are correct in that all the extra resistors in parallel are dropping the resistance too low and the CAN driver(s) cannot handle this much current output.

For most CAN networks, I would agree, 2 120 Ohm resistors should be used.

However, in practice, with lots of branches (especially long ones), 2 resistors may not be enough to maintain the 60 Ohm resistance in the network.

We did a similar CAN setup last year where we had a main line running from a CANivore with every single drivetrain device (8 Falcons, 4 Cancoders) as a separate ~12 inch branch to the trunk. We did have to use more resistors on some of the branches to get the resistance of the network down to 60 Ohms. The hacky way is just to add resistors to branches until it works and stop (which we did; I think we used 4). The more correct way imo would be to measure the resistance and compensate accordingly.
